program_title: Grants for Rural and Native Alaskan Villages
program_description: This program helps remote Alaskan villages provide safe, reliable drinking water and waste disposal systems for households and businesses.
who_can_apply_2: The Alaska Department of Environmental Conservation, on behalf of one or more recipient communities in the state
who_can_apply_3: The Alaska Native Tribal Health Consortium, on behalf of one or more recipient communities in the state
eligible_area_requirement_2: Median household incomes of less than 110 percent of the statewide nonmetropolitan household income (SNMHI) based on the U.S. Census American Community Survey
eligible_area_requirement_2_snmhi_note: Alaska census communities considered high-cost, isolated areas or 'off-the-road systems' that cannot be accessed by normal transportation routes can claim up to 150 percent of the SNMHI
other_requirements_1: Recurring instances of waterborne communicable disease
other_requirements_2: Individual residents hauling water to - or human waste from - their homes, or using outhouses because no community-wide water or wastewater treatment system exists
other_requirements_3: A federal agency such as the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention or a regulatory agency of the state of Alaska determines that the drinking water or wastewater treatment system does not meet current regulations
how_funds_can_be_used: Funds can be used to pay up to 75 percent of project costs to provide safe drinking water or waste disposal services
matching_funds_required: The state of Alaska must provide 25 percent in matching funds from nonfederal sources
how_to_get_started_step_1: Call the USDA-RD RAVG program manager for initial information
how_to_get_started_step_2: Applications are submitted directly to the state of Alaska's Capital Improvements Program
how_to_get_started_step_3: Program resources – including forms, guidance, and certifications – are available online
what_governs_this_program_1: Code of Federal Regulation 7 CFR, Part 1784.8
what_governs_this_program_2: Section 306D of the Agricultural Act of 1961, and the Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act

header_title: Grants for Rural and Native Alaskan Villages
section_title_1: Why does USDA Rural Development do this?
section_content_1: This program helps expand access to clean, reliable water and waste disposal systems for households and businesses enduring dire sanitation conditions in rural or native Alaskan villages. Many Alaskan villages can only be accessed by boat or plane, making them virtually inaccessible during the long winters. Weather and distance also make construction costs abnormally high, and in some cases, permafrost requires the construction of utility tunnels or insulated, heated above-ground pipe in order to provide basic services.
